data.title: Obituary: Cliff Robertson, Oscar-winning actor
data.meta_description: THE new fan base he acquired after appearing as Uncle Ben in Spider-Man in 2002 was “in itself a fine residual” according to Cliff Robertson, the Hollywood star who died of natural causes this week.
data.text:
The revival of his career towards the end of his life would be consolation for the California-born actor who was blacklisted from Hollywood for many years after his involvement in the Begelman scandal of 1977.

Having discovered that a cheque for $10,000 had been unlawfully written in his name, Robertson began an unrelenting investigation into the affair that led to the exposure of much larger-scale fraud in Hollywood.

This made him various enemies in Tinseltown and they put a damper on a career which until then had brought much success.

Robertson was awarded the Oscar for Best Actor in 1968 for his interpretation of a man with special needs in Charly.

He had some practice playing such characters, having portrayed Joan Crawford’s lost soul of a husband in Autumn Leaves 12 years earlier.

His rise to stardom was boosted by roles in various television series such as The Days Of Wine And Roses (1958).

In 1963, John F Kennedy selected him to play the young president in PT 109, depicting the former navy officer’s Second World War heroics, an endorsement which helped bring Robertson’s career to prominence.

In 1965 he won an Emmy for his role in television drama The Game.

Robertson was passionate about aviation and was flying a private plane over the World Trade Center on September 11, 2001, when the first plane hit the North Tower.

The actor was brought up by his Scottish grandmother and uncle in La Jolla, California.
